VOL, XXXV, No. 5

Jay Cage Schedule Contains
Sixteen Opposing Quintets
Team Will Use Loyola Gym Instead of Carlin's
Park; Darley Expects Return Of
Veteran Squad
Coach George Darley today announced the Hopkins basket ball
schedule for 1930-31. It is composed of sixteen games, ten of
Which are to be played with universities and colleges within the
State.
The schedule, which is an especially difficult one, includes games
with such teams as Army, Maryland and Washington College,
among others. It will test the full
strength of Coach Darley's proteges. The schedule is as follows:
December 18—Temple University,
at Philadelphia.
January 6—Loyola College, at Baltimore.
January 9—Polytechnic Institute of
Brooklyn, at Brooklyn.
January 10—Army, at West Point.
January 15—Washington College,
at Baltimore.
January 20—Western Maryland, at
Baltimore.
January 22—University of Maryland,t at Baltimore.
February 13--Washington College,
at Chestertown.
February 17—Western Maryland,
at Westminster.
February 19—Loyola College, at
Baltimore.
February 25—University of Maryland, at College Park.

PROF. HALSEY PRAISES
OUR COLONIAL CULTURE
Invite Hopkins Students To Inspect Annapolitan Landmarks
HOMEWOOD EXAMPLES
St. Johns Authority On Colonial Period Addresses
Dr. R. T. H. Halsey, professor at
St. Johns College, addressed the
student body yesterday at the rgular weekly assembly on the Colonial
period in our history.
After the singing of the University Ode, Francis Warlow introduced r. Halsey, who is an authority on the Colonial period of our
country. Dr. Halsey spoke on the
subject, generally, of Charles Carroll, of Carrollton.
Carrot's Education

Dr. Halsey said that when our
Homewood Club is completely furnished it will represent an outline
of Charles Carroll's life. He proceeded to give the story of his life
from Mr. Carroll's birth in Annapolis, through his eighteen years of
education in Rheims, Paris, Bourges
and London; and then his political
life in America.
The speaker mentioned his great
debt to the Johns Hopkins University, telling how he met various
members of the faculty and discovered that educated men were quite
mman. From this time he began
to educate himself and has been doing so ever since.

With Georgetown, two games with
St. Johns and one game with Pennsylvania Military College, the dates
of which have not as yet been
definitely decided. These will be
announced in the near future.

Hopkins five will take on the strong

GITLOW TO ADDRESS
LIBERAL CLUB TODAY
Tomorrow at 1:15 P. M.
there will be a meeting of the
Liberal Club in Levering Hall.
Luncheon will be served at
12:30 prior to the meeting.
The speaker will be Ben
Gitlow, Communist candidate
for Vice-President in 1928 and
at present leader of the Communist majority group. All
students arc invited to attend.

EDITORIALS
THE CAGE FUND

TWO

announcements concerning basketball were released yesterday. The first concerned the schedule for the 1930-31 season. It
is very similar to that of last year. We note with pleasure the addition of Western Maryland and Pennsylvania Military College. Con.sidering the fact that basketball was re-established at Hopkins only
recently, the teams have been good and the opponents of a high
,calibre. The second announcement was that the Jay team would practice in the Loyola gym.
Some three years ago, a movement was put on foot to finance a
gym for Hopkins. Little has been heard about the so-called Cage
Fund for over a year. It is now said that the matter will have to be
dropped until better business conditions again prevail. The Cage
Fund drive was started shortly after the Levering Hall campaign.
Baltimore business men and Hopkins graduates out of town gave freely
so the latter. The Cage Fund, however, did not meet with similar
success. We believe that this was primarily due to the fact that all
of the prospects had been solicited in the drive for the activities
building. The campaign for the gym met with comparatively good
success on the Homewood Campus. More was pledged for it than
for Levering Hall.
We would like to see a re-opening of the drive for the Cage Fund in
the near future, for we believe it would meet with success now. There
is no question but what a gym is needed. The great majority of Hopkins students have little chance for any physical development at Homewood. The mind will not function unless the body is in a healthy
condition. University authorities realize this, but at present do not
have the necessary capital to erect the kind of a gym that would be
.a credit to Hopkins. Anyone interested in the general welfare of
Hopkins should be glad to contribute to such a cause.
Looking at the situation from the point of view of one interested
in athletics, the great advantage of a gym are obvious. Basketball
teams would improve immensely. Last year, it was all but impossible
for the entire basketball squad to get to Carlin's with any amount of
regularity. Basketball is a game that requires team work to a very
high degree. Team work cannot be obtained without constant and
regular practice. Indoor track and tennis would also be made possible
and hence an improvement in these sports could be expected. Spells
•of bad weather sometimes force the football and lacrosse teams to
suspend practice. With a gym on the campus, some sort of practice
could be continued during these periods.
It would seem that the fact that Hopkins needs a cage, and needs
it badly, would be obvious to anyone. It would also seem that a concentrated and well organized drive would bring the desired results.

New women students at Johns
Hopkins were entertained as a
group for the first time on Sunday
afternoon, when Gamma Chapter
of Phi Delta Gamma was at home
in the Sherwood Room, Levering
Hall. This was the first of the
rushing parties planned by Phi
Delta Gamma, which has the distinction of being the only sorority
on the Hopkins campus and the
only national graduate sorority in
existence.
Miss Isabel Gilbert, president of
the sorority, received the guests and
was assisted by Miss Leona Fehler,
chairman of the rushing committee.
Mrs. T. Jacobs presided at the tea
table. In addition to the new women
students, a number of the faculty
members were present.
The members of Phi Delta
Gamma acting as hostesses were
Miss Eleanor Borzillari, Miss Sarah
Bowditch, Miss Frances Brown,
Miss Lucile Caldwell, Miss Charlotte Campbell, Miss Catherine
Chase, Miss Molly Coggeshall, Miss
Pauline Dieterle, Miss Dorothy
Manasse, Miss Jane Meyer, Miss
Marie Ruzicka, Miss Douglass Rarkin, Miss Mary Solliman, Miss
Hazel B. Thrush, Miss Maryland
Young, Miss Juanita Greer, Miss
Josephine Hopkins, Miss Erma
House and Miss Dorothea Lyford.

The fact is,all these symptoms

according to many authorities.

Universities as far apart as California and Pennsylvania have
found 50% of the men infected.
And the co-eds get it too. Little
Linea trichophyton has made itself a campus pest.
It lurks in the very places

where we all go for cleanliness
and health—on the edges of
swimming pools and showers—
in gymnasiums—on locker-and
dressing room floors. In spite of
modern sanitation (you have to
boil socks 15 minutes to kill it)
this fungus parasite infects and
re-infects bare feet almost any
time they come in contact with
damp floors.

An innovation was established in
track last week when the coach
called the team out for fall practice
for the first time in a number of
years. The practices are being held
daily and consist of limbering-up
exercises and long runs around the
track. A number of men who have
returned this year are out every
afternoon warming up. Among
these are: Lockard, Chassin and
Link, in the sprints; Dorman, in the
weight events; Caldwell and Forrest, in the high jump; Burke, in
the javelin throw, and Quirk, in
both the pole vault and the javelin
throw; Coburn, in the hurdles, and
Milstone, in the distance events.
Several of the long distance men
are training themselves by running
with the cross-country team. Besides this group of yeterans there
are a number of Freshmen out for
the team.

The University of Maryland
team will play Hopkins on January
22 and February 25. Last year
Maryland won both games.
Last year the Hopkins five halved
its series with St. Johns and lost
its lone game with Georgetown.

The show started promptly at the
scheduled hour, to the accompaniment of strains(decidedly strained)
of popular melodies played by the
Blue Jay Orchestra. Then the
master of ceremonies, Bill Rogers,
came upon the scene. Rogers, in
imitation of his famous namesake,
tried to enlighten the gathering,
which was eager to know the latest
in men's wear, by some so-called
wise-cracks. Not in the least whit
discouraged by the impatience of the
mob, he introduced the first mannikin, none other than L. Whiting
Farinholt, ),v hose Barnstormer
training stood him in good stead as
he nonchalantly strolled in, puffing
on a cigarette. Instead of being
greeted by catcalls and jeers, as
could be expected in other circles,
comments as to the symmetry of his
clothing and the coloring of his tie
were heard on all sides.
Perhaps the managers of the
show thought that some manliness
should be ejected into the proceedings, in order to allay the doubts of
any stranger who might be present,
and who never attended college. So
the next character in our little
drama was a mannikin attired in a
varsity football uniform. Then a
gentleman strode in wearing a
"soup and fish" outfit followed by
another clad in so-called campus
clothes. Farinholt next appeared
wearing a lounging robe and a bored
look. Next the center of the stage
was occupied by "Sonny" Kneip, arrayed in the garb of a knight of
the road. Deeming this to be a psychological moment, the next model
introduced was a replica of the Old
Topper as he is pictured by Adolph
Menjou. The next two mannikins
were clothed in oxford gray and
Indian regalia, respectively. To end
the show, a sports costume came
upon the scene, the costume being
motivated by Kneip. His appearance was greeted by many oh's and
oh's, especially after Rogers gave
the price of the coat being $25.
Thus ended the attempt of the
Barnstormers to edify the Hopkins
student regarding the clothing the
well-dressed man should wear. The
only murmurs of discontent were
'heard from those chronic dissenters,
yvho wanted to see the latest in
men's unmentionables. However,
'due to the sobering influence of the
•-Y. M. C. A. building, this was not
done. The presence of women, we
•are sure, would not have detered
the models from exhibiting themselves in silken underthings, for
they would give their all for their
trt. Truly, every day in every way,
'the youth of America is learning to
appreciate the aesthetic things of
life, and is drawing farther and farther away from that rough, hardy
pioneer spirit that makes them sit
on flag-poles.

expects to put a strong team on the

announced, as soon as a definite arrangement can be made with the

Bureau Of Appointments
Trying To Place Students
According to Miss Judge, secretary of the Bureau of Appointments, part-time and full-time outside jobs for Hopkins men are very
scarce, due, of course, to the present
employment situation, though there
have been more applications than
usual. Miss Judge has placed
thirty-three students in various
positions in the biology, psychology
and educational departments and in
the library.
The Bureau will begin its usual
series of talks by representatives of
large business concerns later in the
year. These talks are intended to
advise the Seniors, but underclassmen are invited to attend. The
Bureau also provides substitutes for
the public schools of the city.

ST. REGIS

Several Openings Prominent In Varsity Team To Meet Lehigh
Various Department
At Homewood Tomorrow
Last night at the third rehearsal
of the Musical Club Ronald Levy
was elected to the position of junior
manager. This election was necessitated due to a vacancy left by the
failure of Harold Donovan, whowas
elected to the post last year, to return to the University.
Bruce Peake, president of the
Musical Club, today announced that
there are still openings in the various departments of the organization.
Students who can play the banjomandolin, ukulele or trumpet should
get in touch with him as soon as
possible.
The Banjo Club needs several
banjo-mandolins to balance the tenor
banjos that they now have.
Several good ukelele players are
wanted for the Hawaiian Troupe,
while a good trumpeter has an excellent chance to make the Blue Jay
Orchestra.
Last night musical scores for the
Glee Club's new piece, "Travelin'
to de Grave," were distributed. This
piece is a negro spiritual and follows "The Song of the Jolly
Roger," which the club has been
practicing for the past week.

Dr. L. W. Miles Addresses
Club on Modern Literary
Trends
That the modern practice is to
break away from tradition and form
a tendency largely in contrast to
that for which the Victorians stood
was pointed out by Dr. L. Wardlow
Miles, collegiate professor of English at Hopkins, in his talk before
the Govans Improvement Club,
Tuesday.
The Victorian writers' aim toward
respectability and dignity in their
works is out of fashion in modern
literature, Dr. Miles said.
He explained that though much
is lost in harmony and beauty, a
great deal is gained in frankness
andtruth.
In his talk, the speaker contrasted
novelists, poets and critics of today
with those of the Victorian age.

Wednesday afternon Coach Hambleton conducted a cross-country
meet between the sophomores and
freshmen on the squad, which ended
successfully for the freshmen by the
score of 32-23. The first five men
to finish were Queeringer, who took
first place, Mulstone, Strong, Mele,
and Rapport. The sophomores were
handicapped from the start by the
inability of Packard and Cornman
to run. Cornman was disabled with
an injured leg, which will most likely be healed for the meet with Lehigh tomorrow.

EDITORIALS
THE CAGE FUND

TWO

announcements concerning basketball were released yesterday. The first concerned the schedule for the 1930-31 season. It
is very similar to that of last year. We note with pleasure the addition of Western Maryland and Pennsylvania Military College. Con.sidering the fact that basketball was re-established at Hopkins only
recently, the teams have been good and the opponents of a high
,calibre. The second announcement was that the Jay team would practice in the Loyola gym.
Some three years ago, a movement was put on foot to finance a
gym for Hopkins. Little has been heard about the so-called Cage
Fund for over a year. It is now said that the matter will have to be
dropped until better business conditions again prevail. The Cage
Fund drive was started shortly after the Levering Hall campaign.
Baltimore business men and Hopkins graduates out of town gave freely
so the latter. The Cage Fund, however, did not meet with similar
success. We believe that this was primarily due to the fact that all
of the prospects had been solicited in the drive for the activities
building. The campaign for the gym met with comparatively good
success on the Homewood Campus. More was pledged for it than
for Levering Hall.
We would like to see a re-opening of the drive for the Cage Fund in
the near future, for we believe it would meet with success now. There
is no question but what a gym is needed. The great majority of Hopkins students have little chance for any physical development at Homewood. The mind will not function unless the body is in a healthy
condition. University authorities realize this, but at present do not
have the necessary capital to erect the kind of a gym that would be
.a credit to Hopkins. Anyone interested in the general welfare of
Hopkins should be glad to contribute to such a cause.
Looking at the situation from the point of view of one interested
in athletics, the great advantage of a gym are obvious. Basketball
teams would improve immensely. Last year, it was all but impossible
for the entire basketball squad to get to Carlin's with any amount of
regularity. Basketball is a game that requires team work to a very
high degree. Team work cannot be obtained without constant and
regular practice. Indoor track and tennis would also be made possible
and hence an improvement in these sports could be expected. Spells
•of bad weather sometimes force the football and lacrosse teams to
suspend practice. With a gym on the campus, some sort of practice
could be continued during these periods.
It would seem that the fact that Hopkins needs a cage, and needs
it badly, would be obvious to anyone. It would also seem that a concentrated and well organized drive would bring the desired results.

New women students at Johns
Hopkins were entertained as a
group for the first time on Sunday
afternoon, when Gamma Chapter
of Phi Delta Gamma was at home
in the Sherwood Room, Levering
Hall. This was the first of the
rushing parties planned by Phi
Delta Gamma, which has the distinction of being the only sorority
on the Hopkins campus and the
only national graduate sorority in
existence.
Miss Isabel Gilbert, president of
the sorority, received the guests and
was assisted by Miss Leona Fehler,
chairman of the rushing committee.
Mrs. T. Jacobs presided at the tea
table. In addition to the new women
students, a number of the faculty
members were present.
The members of Phi Delta
Gamma acting as hostesses were
Miss Eleanor Borzillari, Miss Sarah
Bowditch, Miss Frances Brown,
Miss Lucile Caldwell, Miss Charlotte Campbell, Miss Catherine
Chase, Miss Molly Coggeshall, Miss
Pauline Dieterle, Miss Dorothy
Manasse, Miss Jane Meyer, Miss
Marie Ruzicka, Miss Douglass Rarkin, Miss Mary Solliman, Miss
Hazel B. Thrush, Miss Maryland
Young, Miss Juanita Greer, Miss
Josephine Hopkins, Miss Erma
House and Miss Dorothea Lyford.

The fact is,all these symptoms

germ known to the boys in

vegetable kingdom has infected
about half the men in college,
according to many authorities.
The U.S.Health Service reports
that "at least half of all adults
suffer from it at some time."
Universities as far apart as California and Pennsylvania have
found 50% of the men infected.
And the co-eds get it too. Little
Linea trichophyton has made itself a campus pest.
It lurks in the very places

where we all go for cleanliness
and health—on the edges of
swimming pools and showers—
in gymnasiums—on locker-and
dressing room floors. In spite of
modern sanitation (you have to
boil socks 15 minutes to kill it)
this fungus parasite infects and
re-infects bare feet almost any
time they come in contact with
damp floors.

An innovation was established in
track last week when the coach
called the team out for fall practice
for the first time in a number of
years. The practices are being held
daily and consist of limbering-up
exercises and long runs around the
track. A number of men who have
returned this year are out every
afternoon warming up. Among
these are: Lockard, Chassin and
Link, in the sprints; Dorman, in the
weight events; Caldwell and Forrest, in the high jump; Burke, in
the javelin throw, and Quirk, in
both the pole vault and the javelin
throw; Coburn, in the hurdles, and
Milstone, in the distance events.
Several of the long distance men
are training themselves by running
with the cross-country team. Besides this group of yeterans there
are a number of Freshmen out for
the team.

The University of Maryland
team will play Hopkins on January
22 and February 25. Last year
Maryland won both games.
Last year the Hopkins five halved
its series with St. Johns and lost
its lone game with Georgetown.

The show started promptly at the
scheduled hour, to the accompaniment of strains(decidedly strained)
of popular melodies played by the
Blue Jay Orchestra. Then the
master of ceremonies, Bill Rogers,
came upon the scene. Rogers, in
imitation of his famous namesake,
tried to enlighten the gathering,
which was eager to know the latest
in men's wear, by some so-called
wise-cracks. Not in the least whit
discouraged by the impatience of the
mob, he introduced the first mannikin, none other than L. Whiting
Farinholt, ),v hose Barnstormer
training stood him in good stead as
he nonchalantly strolled in, puffing
on a cigarette. Instead of being
greeted by catcalls and jeers, as
could be expected in other circles,
comments as to the symmetry of his
clothing and the coloring of his tie
were heard on all sides.
Perhaps the managers of the
show thought that some manliness
should be ejected into the proceedings, in order to allay the doubts of
any stranger who might be present,
and who never attended college. So
the next character in our little
drama was a mannikin attired in a
varsity football uniform. Then a
gentleman strode in wearing a
"soup and fish" outfit followed by
another clad in so-called campus
clothes. Farinholt next appeared
wearing a lounging robe and a bored
look. Next the center of the stage
was occupied by "Sonny" Kneip, arrayed in the garb of a knight of
the road. Deeming this to be a psychological moment, the next model
introduced was a replica of the Old
Topper as he is pictured by Adolph
Menjou. The next two mannikins
were clothed in oxford gray and
Indian regalia, respectively. To end
the show, a sports costume came
upon the scene, the costume being
motivated by Kneip. His appearance was greeted by many oh's and
oh's, especially after Rogers gave
the price of the coat being $25.
Thus ended the attempt of the
Barnstormers to edify the Hopkins
student regarding the clothing the
well-dressed man should wear. The
only murmurs of discontent were
'heard from those chronic dissenters,
yvho wanted to see the latest in
men's unmentionables. However,
'due to the sobering influence of the
•-Y. M. C. A. building, this was not
done. The presence of women, we
•are sure, would not have detered
the models from exhibiting themselves in silken underthings, for
they would give their all for their
trt. Truly, every day in every way,
'the youth of America is learning to
appreciate the aesthetic things of
life, and is drawing farther and farther away from that rough, hardy
pioneer spirit that makes them sit
on flag-poles.

With an abundance of material
returning this year, Coach Darley
expects to put a strong team on the
floor.
Fritz Stude, Art Siegel, Johnnie
Heinzerling and Bill Gunnett are
the veterans who will probably be
back with the team this season.
It is hoped that Gene Debuskey
will be able to play this year. Due
to his studies at the Medical School
he was able to play in only a few
of the games last year.
Practice will start about the
middle of November, Coach Darley
announced, as soon as a definite arrangement can be made with the
Loyola authorities.

Bureau Of Appointments
Trying To Place Students
According to Miss Judge, secretary of the Bureau of Appointments, part-time and full-time outside jobs for Hopkins men are very
scarce, due, of course, to the present
employment situation, though there
have been more applications than
usual. Miss Judge has placed
thirty-three students in various
positions in the biology, psychology
and educational departments and in
the library.
The Bureau will begin its usual
series of talks by representatives of
large business concerns later in the
year. These talks are intended to
advise the Seniors, but underclassmen are invited to attend. The
Bureau also provides substitutes for
the public schools of the city.

ST. REGIS

Several Openings Prominent In Varsity Team To Meet Lehigh
Various Department
At Homewood Tomorrow
Last night at the third rehearsal
of the Musical Club Ronald Levy
was elected to the position of junior
manager. This election was necessitated due to a vacancy left by the
failure of Harold Donovan, whowas
elected to the post last year, to return to the University.
Bruce Peake, president of the
Musical Club, today announced that
there are still openings in the various departments of the organization.
Students who can play the banjomandolin, ukulele or trumpet should
get in touch with him as soon as
possible.
The Banjo Club needs several
banjo-mandolins to balance the tenor
banjos that they now have.
Several good ukelele players are
wanted for the Hawaiian Troupe,
while a good trumpeter has an excellent chance to make the Blue Jay
Orchestra.
Last night musical scores for the
Glee Club's new piece, "Travelin'
to de Grave," were distributed. This
piece is a negro spiritual and follows "The Song of the Jolly
Roger," which the club has been
practicing for the past week.

Dr. L. W. Miles Addresses
Club on Modern Literary
Trends
That the modern practice is to
break away from tradition and form
a tendency largely in contrast to
that for which the Victorians stood
was pointed out by Dr. L. Wardlow
Miles, collegiate professor of English at Hopkins, in his talk before
the Govans Improvement Club,
Tuesday.
The Victorian writers' aim toward
respectability and dignity in their
works is out of fashion in modern
literature, Dr. Miles said.
He explained that though much
is lost in harmony and beauty, a
great deal is gained in frankness
andtruth.
In his talk, the speaker contrasted
novelists, poets and critics of today
with those of the Victorian age.

Wednesday afternon Coach Hambleton conducted a cross-country
meet between the sophomores and
freshmen on the squad, which ended
successfully for the freshmen by the
score of 32-23. The first five men
to finish were Queeringer, who took
first place, Mulstone, Strong, Mele,
and Rapport. The sophomores were
handicapped from the start by the
inability of Packard and Cornman
to run. Cornman was disabled with
an injured leg, which will most likely be healed for the meet with Lehigh tomorrow.

Race Close

The interclass meet took place
over a two and a half mile course
through Wyman Park. Beside
showing the superiority of the
freshman on the squad this meet
served as experience for the whole
squad. The race was close and
verybody finished strong, which
proved to the coach that the men are
learning to take the strains and assured him that the whole Black and
Blue team will finish on Saturday.
Victory depends on having five men
finish and at least three of them
taking places.
